For me, I enjoy listening to audiobooks because it allows me to multitask while I learn and absorb information. In my opinion, the decision to listen to an audiobook rather than to read a printed book is a matter of personal preference.  There is not really an objective reason that the majority of the population should prefer one medium to the other.  It could come down to preference, or to convenience.

For me, I enjoy listening to audiobooks because it allows me to multitask while I learn and absorb information.  For example, I can perform numerous small tasks around the house or yard that do not require my full attention, yet take up considerable amounts of time.  I can now use this time to learn new subjects or to absorb engaging fiction.  This gives me more opportunities to learn than I would have had if I had to sit down and read a book, without doing anything else.

I would think that you would learn just as much by listening to a book being read to you vs. reading the words off of a page, and it seems to work for me.  Other people might not find it so easy to retain information that they hear.  

So this is one of the key strengths of Audiobooks: the convenience factor.  There are other people who might find it difficult to actually read printed words.  Those who suffer from dyslexia, for example, are just as capable of learning as anyone else, but reading is physically difficult for them.  For these people, audiobooks would be a great improvement over printed words, even if they choose not to multitask.

Obviously, books about art history and fashion would also suffer in an audio format, as photographs are a key part of the material.

The simple fact is, that audiobooks are a great tool, that may be helpful to many people.

If you want to know more, there are apparently over 20,000 audio titles available, and one has to assume that the list is growing at a regular pace.  There are even books that are narrated by their own authors, or by celebrity actors.  

One book that was recently recommended to me is How to Read a Book by Mortimer Adler and Charles Van Doren.  I might pass this recommendation along in either its printed or its audio format to anyone who is interested in reading or listening to more serious educational content in their lives.

As we have seen, absorbing more books may be a lot easier than you think, so what are you waiting for?

I don't have anything else to say, but thousands of authors do!
